fields.description: Currently in Bamboo when branch names contain slashes, the slash are replaced with dashes and as a result, branch names are changed. For example a branch *dev/name* will be renamed in Bamboo as *dev-name*. The build however still reference the branches with their original names as per the attached screenshot. It will be nice not to rename the branches since the build is working correctly.
fields.summary: Slashes in branch names should not be replaced with dashes to avoid ambiguity

But subsequence run on the plan will be fine, the workarea will not be wipe. I have set the priority to be critical as we are migrating bamboo to another server on friday and don't wish that our hundreds of workarea being wipe out.

Saw this ticket but there's no resolution. I thought it should be fixed by version 4.2.1

fields.description:
It now takes you the last completed build. This seems broken, how do I see the active build.

!screenshot.jpg!
fields.summary: Clicking the "rotating" icon at the top right of a build page no longer takes you to the running build.

fields.description: We use both Stash and Bamboo. The Stash instance has been migrated using Stash's built in-migration tool. I'd like to see the same type of tooling in place inside of Bamboo. The migration process involves some complex machinations in order to preserve everything. I've held off in the hope that eventually some automated way would be added.
fields.summary: Provide a database migration function

fields.description:
We use wallboards + bamboo to keep an eye on our builds. Recently we started using plan branches, however the bamboo plans gadget doesn't list plan branches (or allow them to be entered by key). 

It's important that we be able to see the status of plan branches too, as our features are long-lived and require monitoring like any other plan.
fields.summary: Bamboo plan gadget does not allow input of plan branches

fields.description: We build multiple environments from the same code base.  I would like a report that would tell me quickly if the same test is failing on all plans or if different tests are failing on all plans.
fields.summary: Report of failed unit tests across plans

fields.description:
I'm working on nailing down scenarios for this, but what I just noticed is:

* User1 commits, Bamboo picks up, builds and fails a test (in this case, test failure is transient - environment related). Bamboo assigns responsibility to User1.
* User2 commits, Bamboo picks up, builds and fails a different test (the transient test failure is resolved). 

Expected behavior: User2 is added to the responsible user list, User1 is either removed (her test failure is resolved) or remains responsible (until the build is green)

Actual behavior: User1 remains responsible, User2 is _not_ added to the responsible users list.

The behavior around User1 is tricky it seems, in that every test case failure needs to be tied to a user id as well as the fact that some organizations may desire to keep all users tied to failing builds until it succeeds, but it seems that at minimum, User2 should be added to the list.
fields.summary: Automated assignment of responsibility seems to miss when previous failed test is resolved, and new test fails

fields.description:
If you rerun a build, the variable:
{{bamboo.custom.svn.lastchange.revision.number}}
is not set correct.

The SVN plugin uses the last revision of the repository, not the one of the current folder.

The problem only occurs, if you rerun the build.
fields.summary: SVN last change revision incorrect on rerunning a build

fields.description: When an Nunit task is added to a job, Bamboo should automatically add a requirement that the executable for NUNIT must exist similar to what is achieved when adding tasks such as the MSBUILD. This will avoid users from having to manually configure the requirements. Again there are cases where the lack of this will cause builds to fail because the wrong agents (Linux OS agents) for example attempt to pick the build from queue
fields.summary: Capability requirement on jobs shoud be set automatically when Nunit runner task is added

fields.description: URL hacking to next build number yields the goods.
fields.summary: Link to in-progress next build is not working

fields.description: When the plan status history shows an active build, clicking it goes to the latest complete build. Clicking the "build in progress" icon should link to the active build like it does in the project summary.
fields.summary: Clicking a running build in the plan status history only goes to the latest complete build

fields.description:
h3. Summary (Original content by the reporter)
When checking out code, the 'Source Code Checkout' task has an option named 'Force Clean Build' to clean out the directory prior to checking out the code.  I've discovered that although this option is checked, the code directory is not being consistently cleaned out before fresh code is being checked out.

Files that have been deleted from the repository are still present in the per-plan directory on each agent that has run the plan, even after several manual runs of the plan have been run on the agents.  This causes confusion and delay to the builds as outdated information is used.

Please ensure that 'Force Clean Build' actually does what the documentation says it does, that is, remove the directory before running the build.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Install latest Bamboo v5.9.4 (OS does not matter)
# Link to a Git repository
# Create a plan with 2 stages:
## Stage1: It has a single job with 'Source Code Checkout' task
--- It checks out the source code from the linked Git repository
--- It enables 'Force Clean Build'
--- It shares every file as an artifact (i.e. copy pattern: {{\*\*/\*}})
## Stage2: It has a single job with 'Script' task
--- It has a artifact dependency to be shared the artifact
--- It executes {{$ find .}} to check the working copy of the repository
# Execute the plan
# Delete a file from the repository
# Execute the plan again. The log of Stage2 tells that the deleted file is still accessible

h3. Expected Results
The deleted file is not accessible any more

h3. Actual Results
The deleted file is still accessible
 
h3.Workaround
Delete the working directory manually before the plan is run ({{<BAMBOO_HOME>/xml-data/build-dire/<PROJ>\-<PLAN>\-<JOB>}} directory). You may do it in another task which is executed prior to 'Source code checkout' task
fields.summary: 'Force Clean Build' is not honoured

fields.description:
After some cookie-cutter cut'n'paste a while ago, the svn paths in my Bamboo Plans have a number of variables in the middle of them, in this case '$bamboo.name = "project"'.  The automatic branch detection code doesn't work on this, throwing errors in the log like:

  [BambooPluginUtils] An unexpected error has ocurred while detecting branches
  Caused by: com.atlassian.bamboo.repository.RepositoryException: Path 
  https://subversion.example.com/svn/$%7Bbamboo.name%7D/branches does not 
  exist.  Please check configuration of SVN repository in this job.

There is some replacement of Bamboo variables occurring, as the page describing where Bamboo is going to look for branches (Configuration -> Branches -> Subversion Branches URL) fills out the URL as:

  https://subversion.example.com/svn/project/branches

and obviously Bamboo is able to replace the variables and check out the subversion path for the purposes of building the project.

Please pass all instances of the subversion path through the Bamboo variable reconfigulator machine before using them.

(And your Jira instance no longer knows about version 4.3.1 of Bamboo)
fields.summary: Autodetection of branches does not apply bamboo variables to subversion path before talking to subversion.

fields.description:
Requesting to be able to lock some variables in the variables tab.  So that non admin users can update values like their branch without accidentally changing another variable by mistake.  

An example would be to have a lock button that requires an admin password to lock/unlock.  When the variables is locked it will be greyed out.
fields.summary: Ability to Lock Variables

fields.description:
The project summary page, http://localhost:8085/browse/PROJECT, shows info for the default branch.  It would be nice if there was a drop down allowing the user to see info about a given branch.

At our company we have one plan for each module in a project.  Each plan has a release branch and a patch branch.  With a drop down on the project page we could see a summary of which builds are passing/failing for a given branch.
fields.summary: Show branch drop down on project summary page

fields.description:
For a small software team starter license works nicely except that using feature branch auto-detection you run out of jobs really easily. Even having two plans for single or two jobs leads to situation where job limit is reached.

As a workaround we can aggressively delete branches but it's far from ideal.

Suggestion is not to count plan branch jobs when counting job limit.
fields.summary: Bamboo starter license job limit should not count plan branches' jobs

fields.description:
After upgrade to Bamboo 4.3.2 from Bamboo 4.2, the Junit parsing task fails to find test results when the build directory contains symbolic links to sub-directories. What has been changed in the Junit parser that would break the symlinks?

Workaround: add an additional step to copy the test result files to one directory so that the JUnit parsing task can find them.
fields.summary: Junit parsing task fails to recognize symlinks
Add capability to checkout partial direcotries from Git repo

fields.description: Please improve [this page|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/MySQL+5.1] to include the details mentioned in [this KB article|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMKB/MySQL+-+Lock+wait+timeout+exceeded+-+try+restarting+transaction] (READ-COMMITTED transaction isolation level and innodb_lock_wait_timeout variable for MySQL database)
fields.summary: Improve Bamboo documentation - MySQL database configuration

fields.description: Go to any build summary or job summary page for a plan that has at least one in-progress build. In the upper-right strip of icons representing individual builds, click the spinner icon representing an in-progress build. Even though the link URL of that icon points to the correct build number (#370 in this screenshot), it takes you to the last *completed* build (#369 in this screenshot). This happens regardless of which build you started out in - i.e. you could be viewing #368 or #370, but clicking the spinner icon would bring you to #369.
fields.summary: Clicking spinner icon for in-progress job goes to last completed job instead

fields.description: The pages in developer FAQ are outdated with most of the API`s used deprecated. Example of such page is the [How do I start a build programatically|https://developer.atlassian.com/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=1638480]. We will need to update them
fields.summary: Update the Bamboo Developer FAQ in developers.atlassian.com

fields.description: When adding groups in global or plan permissions, the user field is autocomplete which is fine. This is not the case for groups and as such users will have to know the exact group name. See screenshot
fields.summary: Add a group picker or make the text field autocomplete when choosing groups

fields.description:
We're finding that because projects aren't visible on the dashboard they are getting ignored.

When a filter is set, display all projects that are in that filter instead of only the first 4
fields.summary: Improve dashboard visibility experience

fields.description:
https://jira.bamboo.atlassian.com/agent/viewAgents.action?planKey=JIRAMASTER-ORACLE11G-B01&returnUrl=/browse/JIRAMASTER-ORACLE11G-B01/config

This job can only be built in elastic agents. On the moment of the screen shot, there was 26 elastic agents that could built it. 

But the message says "There are currently 52 remote agents online (26 non-elastic and 26 elastic) and capable of building this Job. ". Which is not true. 

And each elastic agent is printed twice. So, 26 elastic agents printed twice == 52 lines.
fields.summary: "Agents that can build that job" seems... weird

fields.description:
Use case: I'd like to retrive the number of failed vs successful builds for a particular project.

E.g. https://bamboo.extranet.atlassian.com/rest/api/latest/result/CAV?start-index=25&expand=results.result.stages

The list of results includes information about the build status but not about whether the plan is disabled/enabled. For this particular use case I don't care about failed builds in disabled projects but I can't easily filter those out (other than requesting the plan status per result which makes it an undesirable {{n+1}} scenario).
fields.summary: REST API: include information about the plan status (enabled/disabled) in the build result resource

fields.description:
I've noticed that elastic agents sometimes fails to start on JBAC due to some S3 communication problem. See the attached log file from the agent. 
In this situation bamboo agent does not start and the spot instance is shut down after 50 minutes.
fields.summary: Elastic agent unable to start with RequestTimeTooSkewed

fields.description: Replace "NoSuchElementException" with something more meaningful please :)
fields.summary: Error message on Editing Elastic Image Configuration is unclear when the Bamboo EC2 account doesn't have permission to view / launch the AMI

fields.description:
We are using JIRA of a Japanese-language version.
We will also use Bamboo.
I am investigating the Bamboo and the connection with JIRA.

However, Bamboo turns into garbage characters.
So, we are not able to confirm the release information and create the issue from Bamboo.
I attached the 2 images.
fields.summary: Bamboo turns into garbage characters.

fields.description: In case applinks break and there is need to remove them and recreate, the project links are getting deleted too. When deleting application links, allow Bamboo admin an option to delete the project links between Bamboo and JIRA projects or keep them (the same way that we save the issue/build links).
fields.summary: Provide flexibility to delete or keep Project links from Bamboo to JIRA

fields.description:
Supply a versionId and get the correct Bamboo build key that was released with it via REST API.

Current REST API need to be supplied with both version ID and build key:
* /bamboo/status/{jiraVersionId}/{planResultKey}

It will be better if user need to provide only the version ID and the API will come out with any Bamboo build's result that linked to that version ID.
fields.summary: Supply a versionId and get the correct Bamboo build key that was released with it via REST API

fields.description:
Currently when a remote agent spins up and has its capabilities changed, the change is only reflected on the Bamboo server when the capability is new. If the capability already exists, it is not modified due to the possibility that a user has overwritten the value on the server side.

Ideally there should be an option for Bamboo to unconditionally trust a remote agent's reported capabilities and update the server values accordingly to support environments where such provisioning of capabilities is automated.
fields.summary: There should be an option for remote agents to always prefer bamboo-capabilities properties as opposed to server values when resolving capability conflicts

fields.description:
When a spot EC2 instance is provisioned, and the price increases dramatically between the bid submission and the actual spinup, Bamboo reflects the current spot price as opposed to the price at which the instance was obtained at.

Ideally it should be an accurate reflection of the spot price, failing which it should show the maximum bid as opposed to the current spot price to avoid unnecessary heart attacks.
fields.summary: Spot instance prices can sometimes be inaccurate

fields.description: If I click on the spinning icon for the current build, it doesn't actually navigate to that build any more.  This worked a week ago but is broken now in "4.4-M3 build 3500 - 11 Dec 12"
fields.summary: Navigate to running build is broken

fields.description:
When I go to a plan and there are, say, 70 builds in the history and the 71st is building, and I click on the 71th's throbber icon, I expect to reach the 71st build.

Since this week (yesterday?), it leads me to the build #70 and there's nowhere to click to reach the 71st, I need to write its url.
fields.summary: Clicking the last build's icon should lead me to the last build
Extend dependency blocking strategy to be applicable to triggers based on a schedule or via a parent build

fields.summary: Add Bamboo Server validation does not correctly validate URI

fields.description:
To duplicate this bug:
# Configure Application Link to a JIRA instance with Trusted Applications for both incoming and outgoing authentication.
# Create a JIRA project X with a security scheme and a default security level.
# From Bamboo, Create Issue in project X. See attached error message:
!bamboo-jira-bug.jpg!

When project X is set to not use any security scheme, JIRA ticket can be created from Bamboo.
fields.summary: Cannot create JIRA issue when JIRA project has a security scheme

fields.description:
According to [https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Linking+JIRA+issues+to+a+build], only a pattern matching 2 or more letters followed by dash and numeric sequence would be considered as JIRA issue keys.
I was able to reproduce that that the pattern is matching any characters including digits: 

12-18-2012T16-18-20 (time stamp included into distribution package file path we would like to mention in the comment) gets parsed as

JIRA Issues
-------------
12-18
2012T16-18
fields.summary: Build comment is being incorrectly parsed in search for JIRA issues

{code}
fields.summary: LDAP user being logged out on starring a build plan

fields.description:
When cloning one of our Git repos using the cli, all execute permissions on .sh and .pl files are set (755). However, when Bamboo clones the same repo, all execute permissions are UNset (644). This bug recently caused an incident in production. What gives?

Thanks very much
fields.summary: Execute Permissions Unset in Git Clone After Upgrading to Bamboo 4.3.2

fields.description: Please explicitly specify on the documentation that Bamboo Remote agents inherit the paths of the shared capability executables - NOT the actual executable files. This means that every time a user configures a capability for an agent, he needs to make sure that the executable file (Ant, Maven) exists in that location on the remote server where the remote agent will run. The first paragraph on [this page|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Configuring+a+shared+executable+capability] and other related sections can be considered to be improved.
fields.summary: Improve Bamboo documentation - shared agent capabilities

fields.description:
Bamboo seems to parse password at '&'

From Customer ticket:

This blog post discuss how to use Bitbucket repositories in Bamboo:

http://blog.bitbucket.org/2012/07/24/continuous-integration-bamboo-ondemand-bitbucket/

Here is the error that I receive in my build when I use https://bitbucket.org/baschmedia/gizmofolioservice:

System Error Details
Build GIZMOFOLIO - GIZMOFOLIO - Default Job 2 : Executing Task 'Checkout Default Repository(1)' of type com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.vcs:task.vcs.checkout.
(java.lang.RuntimeException : com.atlassian.bamboo.repository.RepositoryException: Cannot fetch branch '(unresolved) 01d9cd88b5e40c2992d0e5537223488485aa8b67' from 'https://bitbucket.org/baschmedia/gizmofolioservice' to source directory 'C:\build-dir\GIZMOFOLIO-GIZMOFOLIOBUILD-JOB1'. command 'c:\Program Files (x86)\Git\bin\git.exe' ls-remote https://baschmedia:Kf%40&7q%2FvU1W&VglSNS5hEhBUcRQOx8C!ovL*y%5CZxSRAmG8''%5C=9H0%5E%6023SU%25$wmy@bitbucket.org/baschmedia/gizmofolioservice failed with code 1. Working directory was [C:\build-dir\GIZMOFOLIO-GIZMOFOLIOBUILD-JOB1]., stderr: [error: Couldn't resolve host 'baschmedia:Kf%40' while accessing https://baschmedia:Kf%40/info/refs, fatal: HTTP request failed, '7q%2FvU1W' is not recognized as an internal or external command,, operable program or batch file., 'VglSNS5hEhBUcRQOx8C!ovL*y%5CZxSRAmG8''%5C' is not recognized as an internal or external command,, operable program or batch file.])
fields.summary: Bamboo fails to connect with special characters in the password field (particularly '&')

fields.description:
If the db isn't available the build plan won't finish gracefully. It will look like it's still working and say something like "Build: #1883 is building - 3376 mins slower than usual Scheduled with changes by USER"

The last text in the build output looks like
{code}
14-Dec-2012 22:07:07	Running on server: post build plugin 'Maven Dependencies Postprocessor'
14-Dec-2012 22:07:07	Failed to execute plugin 'Maven Dependencies Postprocessor' with error: Could not open Hibernate Session for transaction; nested exception is net.sf.hibernate.exception.GenericJDBCException: Cannot open connection
14-Dec-2012 22:07:07	All post build plugins have finished
{code}

Clicking "stop the build" seems to have no effect. Plan can't be run because bamboo thinks that it's still running.

The only way to fix this is a restart of bamboo.

I'm putting 4.3.2 as the affected version because that's the version I'm currently looking at., even though this behaviour has been around for quite a while.
fields.summary: Postprocessors should time out if can't get a connection to the db

fields.description:
# on "my bamboo" plan (logged in as admin)
# mouse over disable button. URL looks like http://example.com/bamboo/build/admin/resumeBuild.action?buildKey=PROJECTKEY-PLANKEY
# click on button
# get taken to a page with URL http://example.com/bamboo/build/buildConfiguration.action?buildKey=
# text on page is like 'An unexpected error has occurred Could not find the "" build'
# plan is correctly enabled / disabled
fields.summary: Disabling plan from "my bamboo" tabs redirects to page that doesn't exist

fields.description:
It is possible that this is a problem with the bamboo agent, but I am not sure.

My Lettuce/Python tests start and after killing all previously running Firefox or Python processes, the tests stop for between 10-15 minutes.
No log is received during this time.
The tests start again, but they will stop again for another 10 minutes after a while.

In many cases, the tests do not complete at all, after running for more than 4 hours - locally, they run in 5 minutes.
fields.summary: Tests in Bamboo hung every other 10 minutes

fields.description:
When expanding or collapsing test failures, it takes an incredibly long time if you have more than, say, 10 test failures.

It seems that this is because the expand/collapse buttons are iterating through each DOM element and manually triggering a click on each and every one of them in sequence.

The attached screenshot demonstrates the significance of this problem in Chrome with 50 test failures. It takes Chrome about 1.2 seconds with 50 tests. This gets progressively worse with more tests. It causes IE8 have a heart attack. Poor IE8.

Can we make this... faster?
fields.summary: Performance of expand/collapse test failures is quite slow

fields.description:
When viewing a JIRA issue one can see Bamboo activity in the Builds tab however Bamboo activity is not shown in JIRA's 'All' tab.

This is in contrast to the DVCS connector where relating commits show in the Commits tab as well as the All tab
fields.summary: Bamboo activity not shown in JIRA's 'All' tab

fields.description:
I've added a NUnit runner task for our project. When triggering a build, everything runs fine, up to the point where the unit tests will be executed. 

I get the following output:

Could not find test result reports in the C:\Program Files (x86)\Atlassian\Application Data\Bamboo\xml-data\build-dir\SILOM-GREEN-JOB1 directory.

Unbehandelte Ausnahme: System.FormatException: GUID muss 32 Ziffern mit 4 Bindestrichen enthalten (xxxxxxxx-xxxx-xxxx-xxxx-xxxxxxxxxxxx).
   bei System.Guid..ctor(String g)
   bei NUnit.Agent.NUnitTestAgent.Main(String[] args)

VisualStudio Professional 2012 as our IDE
The project is written in C# .Net4.5
Git as version control solution (with SCM-Manager as out repository-management-solution)
Bamboo 4.3.2 build 3402 on a Windows 2008 R2
fields.summary: NUnit console application throws a format-exception, when triggered by NUnitRunner.
Plan Result Summary shows status from the first defined Job

fields.description: Manual triggers use a different lock than other builds, so people can accidentally trigger two builds leading to all sorts of trouble.
fields.summary: Manual builds mixed with scheduled/triggered builds can go over build concurrency limit

fields.description:
I wish I could set up a job the following way:
task1: source code checkout 
task2: mvn integration-test
task3: mvn deploy (only runs on main plan branch, not on auto detected branches.)

This is to be able to share build configuration, but not deploy feature-branch artifacts to our nexus repository.

I'd love to have two flags in all task types 
-run on default plan branch only
-run on branches only
fields.summary: Make tasks feature branch aware

This is particularly important because sometimes different users tend to add different executables that eventual becomes global conflicting with the added ones by admins. See screenshot

fields.description:
During some of our java builds, we sometimes encounter a network error when retrieving jar files from remote repositories, preventing the build from completing.  Re-running the build results in the jar files being retrieved, the build being completed, and everything being happy.

An improvement to Bamboo would be the ability for an individual task to be retried N times until it succeeds or fails all of the retries, without failing the overall build.  A little checkbox in the labeled 'Retry this task up to', a pulldown with numbers 1-5 and 'times' would do the trick, presentation-wise.
fields.summary: Option to retry tasks during Build

fields.description:
On pages which display the Plan name in the header with a dropdown containing branches ( such as /browse/<plan-id> ) the current behavior is as follows:

For the default branch, the name displayed for the branch is the branch name in the repository.

For other branches in the plan, the name displayed is the Display Name as configured on the branch settings within the plan.

This causes confusion if the same repository branch is being used in different bamboo branches with different variable settings - leading to cases where the name displayed is the same.

In our case, I have a staging environment which uses the same repository branch called prod - but has different settings.  And I purposefully want the default job to NOT be the production environment.  This leads to two items in the dropdown labeled "prod" -- when one is actually staging.
fields.summary: Create a Display Name for the default Branch within a plan (or a repository)

fields.description: After expiring build logs,'Download' and 'View' links under build results' Logs page refer to 'Page Not Found'. These 2 links shouldn't be shown if there are no build logs for the current build result. Attached are screenshots indicating the issue.
fields.summary: 'Download' and 'View' links under build results' Logs page refer to 'Page Not Found'

fields.description:
When I disable a task, it is automatically saved. The disabled lozenge shows up next to the task in the list. I can navigate away from the page as soon as I tick that box. The next build won't execute it. 

If I re-enable a task, the lozenge is removed, and the thing "looks" re-enabled... except it isn't. If I don't explicitly "Save" the task, then I navigate away from the page, it will remain disabled.

I have been bitten as I re-enabled a task, then clicked in to the last build that ran to re-run it. It didn't do what I expected, as the task was technically disabled, even though it appeared that my re-enabling of it was successful.
fields.summary: Automatically save a task when its disabled state changes

fields.description:
Looking at JavaDoc published for Bamboo 4.3 and saw : http://docs.atlassian.com/atlassian-bamboo/latest/com/atlassian/bamboo/labels/LabelManager.html#hasPlanLabel%28com.atlassian.bamboo.plan.Plan,%20java.lang.String%29

The method is named "hasPlanLabel" witha parameter of a Plan and a Label, but the description reads "Checks whether the build results summary has a particular label".

Should this read something more like "Checks whether the Plan has a particular label"
fields.summary: JavaDoc Typo in LabelManager.hasPlanLabel

fields.description:
Currently the pattern to detect Maven Capabilities is "Apache Maven (\\S+) .*"

However its possible to get the output as 

{code}
$ mvn -version
Apache Maven 3.0.4
Maven home: /usr/share/maven
Java version: 1.6.0_37, vendor: Sun Microsystems Inc.
Java home: /usr/lib/jvm/java-6-sun-1.6.0.37/jre
Default locale: en_US, platform encoding: UTF-8
OS name: "linux", version: "3.2.0-29-generic", arch: "amd64", family: "unix"
{code}
The pattern assumes there is another sequence of information after the 3.0.4

Suggestion from customer: Change pattern to "Apache Maven (\\S+) ?.*"
fields.summary: Maven 3 Capability Detector Fails in some cases.

fields.description:
When I go to the build queue in the currentActivity my primary reason is to promote the build I care about to the top of the queue so it's executed as soon as possible.

To do it now I need to find my build on the queue and drag it to the top, quickly enough to finish it before the top build is taken from the queue because otherwise I need to do it again (d&d fails)

I have never felt a need to fine-tune the build order, so drag&drop has little value to me.
What I need there is an arrow button that would bring given build to the top of the queue.

What I really need, though, is an "Expedite" Action in the context of a build that is in "in the queue" state so I can do what I need without browsing to dashboard & finding the build visually on the list
fields.summary: Queue reordering should make "bring to front" the most obvious action

https://wiki.jenkins-ci.org/display/JENKINS/Parameterized+Build

As a plan creators they want to be able to say:

"These three variables are required and these two variables are optional."
When the build is run, a form comes up, showing the variables to the user:

Example:
Release name: (Pull down of multiple release names the job creator has defined)
Please enter the name of the release you want to build from the pull down above.

Your SVN user id: (Pull down from valid user ids or free form text)
Please enter the user id you use for SVN.

Your SVN password: (A hidden input field)
Please enter your SVN password above.

Additional users to notify: (Multi-pick field based on users of system.)
Please add any additional users you would like to notify.

Project to charge build to: (Pick list defined by plan creator showing cost centers.)
Please enter the cost center for this build.

fields.description:
Basically the following use case is not handled well:

* Reviewing a build that has quarantined tests
* All tests are magically green
* Ok, so *who quarantined* these so I can go talk to them to find out more information (are they flakey, or waiting for a fix, did someone forgot to unleash them?). (*James Dumay*: Fixed in 5.0)
* Flakey? How long have then been green, in time, for how many consecutive builds.

Possible solutions:

* More columns in the summary screen.
** Who quarantined a test.
** How long it's been green, time, since build.
* Show the test history page as a pop-up when hovering over the "history" icon.
* Allow the user to provide a reason for quarantining a test.
* Allow quarantining for a certain amount of time (i.e. 1 day, 1 week, etc).
fields.summary: Timeout and reason for test quarantine

fields.description:
By default the "test" tab in Bamboo only shows failures / quarantined jobs.

When there's only a single job the "left panel" is hidden behind a very small, grey triangle on the center-left.

Clicking on the triangle, then the job allows the user to find "all tests". 

I couldn't figure out to do this at all. Some help on the "build engineering" channel pointed me in the right direction.

This should be easier to find, or there should be other ways to navigate there (e.g. I was expecting a link where it says "93 tests in total").

!screenshot.jpg!
fields.summary: Finding "all tests" was near impossible on a plan with only 1 job.

fields.description:
We have a 100-agent bamboo instance licensed. What happens when we reach the 100-agent limit? Are further remote agents blocked from being registered, or if they are allowed to be registered with bamboo does it cause a breach of license or support? 

I recently installed a bamboo server in a test/dev environment and ran a script to spin up 100+ remote agents pointing back at Bamboo. It seemed to allow all ~110 agents to be registered without even a warning or message that I had exceeded my license limitation.

My concern with this is that in our production 100-agent instance we allow multiple internal teams to stand up remote agents and have crossed the 50-60 agent mark out of our 100 agents licensed. If we hit 100 we may not even know until manual inspection but if it happens and goes unnoticed for a few days/weeks then we may be out of compliance with the license or be violating support terms. 

Any features to help prevent this would be nice (and any real world guidance on some of the concerns above would also be helpful).
fields.summary: System Notification or Warning When You Reach Maximum Number of Remote Agents You Are Licensed For

fields.description:
In Bamboo admin section, in the Global Permissions section I enabled ACCESS for Anonymous users.

On one Plan, Anonymous users have View permissions for the plan. If as that anonymous user I navigate to the Plan and then paste a URL into my browser bar for deleting a comment it allows me to Delete the Plan Comment.

/build/ajax/deleteComment.action?commentId=4784131&buildKey=BAMBOO-TASKS&buildNumber=1

I would not think that an anonymous user, even with view permissions to the Plan, should be able to delete a comment.
fields.summary: Anonymous Users With View Permissions Can Delete Plan Comments

fields.description:
There are 2 Java Code coverage tool plugins for Bamboo - both are dead projects that development ended years ago.

There is a new Java Code coverage tool that is under active development JaCoCo. This tool supports Java 7 and was not difficult to integrate into ant. You need a java code coverage plugin that supports this tool.

Like I said in ticket BAM-12495 - this plugin on the plan summary screen needs to show the progress graphically of the code coverage over time. I will include a checkstyle/findbugs screen shot - but extend the idea to code coverage.
fields.summary: Java Code Coverage Tool Plugins only exist for Java Code Coverage projects abandoned years ago and do not support Java 7

fields.description:
I'm moving from Jenkins to Bamboo and woefully disappointed in the information presented in the bamboo UI plan page. 

The current UI only show success or failure of last N builds and time to compile statistics. There is no summary information concerning JUnit pass/warn rates nor feedback on the number of checkstyle/findbug warnings and their severity. The same is true for the total code coverage. I will file a separate ticket concerning the code coverage plugin support. Where code coverage is concerned, the percent code coverage by file and by number of lines would be useful. 

I will attach screen shots of example feedback that I was getting in Jenkins. Unfortunately I have cleaned the code up so much that the number of errors on some items is zero for a small fixed number for the last several builds.
fields.summary: Progress Feedback on JUnit, CheckStyle, Findbugs and Java Coverage is lacking

fields.description: Additionally, I would like this to be supported :)
fields.summary: As a developer I want drag and drop auto-config of a plan based on an Xcode Project

fields.description:
Since quarantined tests don't delegate down branch plan configs, I often find myself doing the following click orgy:

# check the execution on my branch, and determine if I merged stuff in a bad state from upstream in or I caused the failure, e.g. https://confluence-bamboo.atlassian.com/browse/CONFFUNC-MAIN183-104/test
# in order to determine if the test was quarantined, I try to find the plan testing the commit of the merge-base on default, e.g.{code}
git merge-base canonical/master canonical/issue/pdl_development
999e9474eadd2465e9502c03a83b6190fffc92c2
{code}https://confluence-bamboo.atlassian.com/browse/CONFFUNC-MAIN-BATCH7-13961/commit
# now I could assume that I produced the failure on the branch, or better check https://confluence-bamboo.atlassian.com/browse/CONFFUNC-MAIN-13961 to see that there are quarantined tests for that execution, so I go to https://confluence-bamboo.atlassian.com/browse/CONFFUNC-MAIN-13961/test 
# now I could check the latest build on upstream to see if they are fixed now, so I go to https://confluence-bamboo.atlassian.com/browse/CONFFUNC-MAIN/latest
# now I want to know who quarantined legitimate test failures, but this information is not presented on https://confluence-bamboo.atlassian.com/browse/CONFFUNC-MAIN-13965/test/#quarantined-tests
# so I go back to the plan view, https://confluence-bamboo.atlassian.com/browse/CONFFUNC-MAIN and click on "Quarantined Tests" https://confluence-bamboo.atlassian.com/browse/CONFFUNC-MAIN/quarantine

I think we can make this much more convenient. The optimal implementation would be sth. like:

#When a branch config is executed, determine the merge-base with upstream/default and save it for this execution
#When the execution is over and the test results are parsed, determine the corresponding execution on upstream/default and see if the test failed there too
#Show the following information on the test result view for the branch execution
* test failed for merge-base run on upstream/default
* test is still failing on upstream/default
* test is quarantined on upstream/default, who quarantined it and ask if you would like to quarantine
fields.summary: Convenient default/upstream test failure comparison for Git based plans

fields.description:
I've created a Hg repository in BitBucket, cloned it locally, added a dumb file, committed it, and pushed back into BitBucket.

In Bamboo I've created a plan that uses this repository, and executed the initial clean build.

Then I've modified the file and committed it two more times using these commit messages:
* Second time:
{noformat}
Commit utilizando palavras com acentuações. Atualização, compilação, correção, publicação, execução
{noformat}
* Third time:
{noformat}
Commit utilizando palavras com acentuações. Correção, execução
{noformat}

When Bamboo polled the repo again and kicked off the second build, this was the result in *Code Changes* section:
!code_changes.jpg!

I've tried to reproduce the problem using a local SVN repo, and no errors were displayed.
fields.summary: Character encoding errors when Hg Mercurial from BitBucket is used
Location of settings.xml and the Maven repository path are broken for Maven Dependency Processor

fields.description: While editing the config of a Plan, I have a Subversion repo defined. If I go to the Source Repo tab, click the Subversion repo in the list I view the Repo details. I click the arrow next to Advanced Options. I scroll down the page to the field named Web Repository. If I change it from 'None' to 'Generic Web Repository' the field appears named 'Web Repository URL'. It is marked with a red asterisk to indicate a required field. However, if I click Save Repository, the Subversion repo is saved and I see the green success message of "Repository updated successfully". I would think I should be unable to save the repository details if the 'Web Repository URL' field were truly required.
fields.summary: Invalid Validation of Web Repository field in Subversion Repo Advanced Options

fields.description: While editing the config of a Plan, I have a Subversion repo defined. If I go to the Source Repo tab, click the Subversion repo in the list I view the Repo details. I click the arrow next to Advanced Options. I scroll down the page to the field named ""Include / Exclude Files". I set the field from 'None' to 'Include only changes...'. The 'File Pattern' field is now displayed. There is no asterisk next to it to indicate it is required field. If I click Save Repository button without entering anything into the File Pattern field, the screen refreshes and the advanced options are hidden, as if it saved the settings with no error or warning displayed. This would lead a user to think it worked. However, if I click the down arrow next to Advanced Options and scroll down, next to the File Pattern field, I see a red error message "you must enter a regex expression". I would think this should somehow have been displayed, and not hidden when the advanced options were hidden after clicking the Save Repository button.
fields.summary: Invalid Validation of File Pattern field in Subversion Repo Advanced Options

fields.description: In the Plan Audit log, the list of audit events can grow quite long, and paginated across numerous pages, is difficult to examine for changes. It would be nice if there was an ability to click the column header of one field and have the pages sorted by that column. A common use case for an audit log like this one is to examine all the occurrences where a field was changed regardless of date. In an audit log with dozens of pages it is not easy to do.
fields.summary: Plan Audit Log - Sort Columns
